task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for Ali Khaledi Nasab's current employment and professional connections in AI research
task_1.data:
As of 2024, Dr. Ali Khaledi Nasab is a scientist at Amazon Rufus, focusing on Generative AI products. He transitioned to this role after serving as a research scientist at Amazon Web Services (AWS) in the Network Capacity Planning organization. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab has an extensive background in physics and neuroscience, which has naturally led him into the field of artificial intelligence. His expertise encompasses machine learning, deep learning, nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. He is dedicated to continuous learning, allocating two hours daily to reading and coursework. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In 2024, he was appointed as an Adjunct Professor of Physics at Ohio University and delivered a colloquium talk at the university's Department of Physics. Additionally, he served as the editor for the Brain Development section of the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," a collaborative work that received the 2024 PROSE Award for significant contributions in Clinical Medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab's professional network includes affiliations with Amazon, Ohio University, and Stanford University. He has also been associated with the Ronin Institute as a researcher. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio?utm_source=openai))

For more detailed information about his professional journey and contributions, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_2.query_used: Search Google Scholar and ResearchGate for academic publications by Ali Khaledi Nasab in artificial intelligence
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher affiliated with Amazon, specializing in machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

His work in artificial intelligence includes studies on desynchronization effects in neural networks. In "Long-lasting desynchronization of plastic neural networks by random reset stimulation," Khaledi-Nasab and colleagues explore how random reset stimulation can induce prolonged desynchronization in neural networks, which has potential applications in treating neurological disorders. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Another notable publication is "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," where Khaledi-Nasab investigates methods to reduce polarization in social networks using random dynamical interventions, contributing to the understanding of information dissemination and opinion dynamics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, in "Impact of number of stimulation sites on long-lasting desynchronization effects of coordinated reset stimulation," he examines how varying the number of stimulation sites affects the efficacy of coordinated reset stimulation in achieving sustained desynchronization in neural networks. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

These publications highlight Khaledi-Nasab's contributions to applying artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques to complex systems in neuroscience and network dynamics.

task_3.query_used: Search IEEE Xplore and ACM Digital Library for conference papers authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data:
I searched for conference papers authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab in the IEEE Xplore and ACM Digital Library databases but did not find any relevant results. However, according to his Google Scholar profile, Ali Khaledi-Nasab has contributed to several research areas, including machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

One notable publication is "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," co-authored with CB Currin and S Vallejo Vera, published in *Scientific Reports* in 2022. This study explores methods to reduce polarization in social networks by introducing random dynamical interventions. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Another significant work is "Long-lasting desynchronization of plastic neural networks by random reset stimulation," co-authored with JA Kromer and PA Tass, published in *Frontiers in Physiology* in 2021. This research investigates techniques for inducing sustained desynchronization in neural networks, which has implications for treating neurological disorders. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Ali Khaledi-Nasab authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in *Science* in 2017. In this piece, he discusses the challenges faced by international students in the United States following the 2016 presidential election and advocates for institutional support to address these issues. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

While specific conference papers by Ali Khaledi Nasab in IEEE Xplore and ACM Digital Library were not found, his contributions to various research fields are well-documented in other reputable journals and platforms.

citations.title: (PDF) Standing up to fear | Ali Khaledi Nasab - Academia.edu

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. He has a diverse background in physics, neuroscience, and artificial intelligence, with expertise in nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. His research interests include machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai), [scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

For more information about his work and publications, you can visit his personal website at [alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/) or his Google Scholar profile. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai), [scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

task_6.query_used: Search news articles and press releases mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab in context of AI research or technology
task_6.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has made significant contributions to the field of physics, particularly in the study of excitable networks and sensory neurons. In October 2017, as a graduate student in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University, he delivered a colloquium at the College of Wooster titled "Emergent Stochastic Oscillations and Signal Detection in Tree Networks of Excitable Elements." His research focused on the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to sensory neurons like cat muscle spindles. The study demonstrated that the spontaneous activity of such networks could be predicted by analyzing a single effective node with scaled parameters, suggesting mechanisms for tuning the activity of central elements in these networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

In May 2019, Khaledi Nasab received a Student Travel Award from the American Physical Society's Division of Biological Physics, enabling him to present his paper, "Dynamics of Excitable Tree Networks: Application to Sensory Neurons," at the APS annual meeting in Boston. His research aimed to understand the dynamical principles of functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies, such as those found in muscle spindles, pain receptors, mechanoreceptors, and electroreceptors. Utilizing theoretical and computational approaches, he investigated mechanisms of spike generation and information coding in these neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

As of 2024, Khaledi Nasab is a Senior Researcher at Amazon in Seattle, United States, and also affiliated with the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

While his earlier work primarily focused on physics and neuroscience, there is no publicly available information directly linking Ali Khaledi Nasab to AI research or technology.

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Gives Colloquium Talk at College of Wooster - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences
Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_7.query_used: Search university websites and faculty directories for Ali Khaledi Nasab's academic affiliations
task_7.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist with a diverse academic and professional background. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. in Physics at Ohio University, where he focused on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

After completing his doctorate, Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined the Department of Neurosurgery at Stanford University School of Medicine as a postdoctoral researcher. There, he worked on designing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

In 2022, he transitioned to the tech industry, joining Amazon Web Services (AWS) as a research scientist in the Network Capacity Planning organization. By 2024, he moved to Amazon Rufus to work on their latest Generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his roles at Amazon, Dr. Khaledi Nasab serves as an adjunct professor of Physics at Ohio University, a position he began in 2024. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has contributed to various fields, including physics, neuroscience, and artificial intelligence, reflecting his interdisciplinary expertise and commitment to advancing scientific knowledge.

task_11.query_used: Search court records and legal databases for any litigation involving Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_11.data:
After searching court records and legal databases, I found no litigation involving an individual named "Ali Khaledi Nasab." It's possible that such records are not publicly available, the individual has not been involved in any legal proceedings, or the name may be spelled differently in legal documents.

However, I did find cases involving individuals with similar names:

1. **Khaledi v. Global Trading Ltd HAR (2003):** This case involved Heydar "Shaun" Khaledi in a business dispute with H.K. Global Trading, Ltd. and others. The litigation centered around a temporary injunction related to a business disagreement among the Khaledi brothers. ([caselaw.findlaw.com](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/court/tx-court-of-appeals/1109873.html?utm_source=openai))

2. **Kholghi v. Aliabadi (2020):** This Tennessee Court of Appeals case involved Sima Khayatt Kholghi and Reza Aliabadi in a divorce proceeding. The court addressed issues related to the division of marital assets and debts. ([law.justia.com](https://law.justia.com/cases/tennessee/court-of-appeals/2020/m2019-01793-coa-r3-cv.html?utm_source=openai))

3. **Alami v. Khalid (2024):** In this Ohio Court of Appeals case, Ali Alami filed a complaint against Hassan Khalid and others concerning a joint venture to purchase equipment. The dispute involved claims of replevin, money damages, and unjust enrichment. ([casetext.com](https://casetext.com/case/alami-v-khalid?utm_source=openai))

Please note that these cases involve individuals with similar but not identical names to "Ali Khaledi Nasab." If you have additional information, such as alternative spellings, locations, or specific case details, I can assist further in locating relevant records.

citations.title: KHALEDI v. GLOBAL TRADING LTD HAR (2003) | FindLaw
Sima Khayatt Kholghi v. Reza Aliabadi :: 2020 :: Tennessee Court of Appeals Decisions :: Tennessee Case Law :: Tennessee Law :: US Law :: Justia
Alami v. Khalid, 2024 Ohio 2456 | Casetext Search + Citator

task_12.query_used: Search professional networking sites and AI community forums for mentions of Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_12.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher affiliated with Amazon, specializing in machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. His Google Scholar profile lists numerous publications in these areas, indicating a significant contribution to the field. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

On the Quantum Computing Stack Exchange, a user named "Ali" from Mashhad, Iran, has been a member for over six years, with a professional focus on quantum computation, quantum optics, and condensed matter. This user has a reputation score of 113 and has provided answers related to quantum algorithms and quantum gates. ([quantumcomputing.stackexchange.com](https://quantumcomputing.stackexchange.com/users/2023/ali?utm_source=openai))

Similarly, on the Software Engineering Stack Exchange, a user named "Ali" from Mashhad, Iran, has been a member for over 11 years, with a professional focus on quantum computation, quantum optics, and condensed matter. This user has a reputation score of 101 but has not posted any questions or answers. ([softwareengineering.stackexchange.com](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/users/91388/ali?utm_source=openai))

While the Stack Exchange profiles do not explicitly confirm that these users are the same individual as the researcher at Amazon, the shared name and overlapping research interests suggest a possible connection.

User Ali - Software Engineering Stack Exchange

report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 11, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a scientist at Amazon Rufus, specializing in Generative AI products. He has a strong background in physics, neuroscience, and AI, including machine learning, deep learning, and computational neuroscience.  There are no apparent red flags based on the provided OSINT data.

### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**
- Currently Scientist at Amazon Rufus, working on Generative AI products (as of 2024).
- Previously Research Scientist at Amazon Web Services (AWS) in Network Capacity Planning.
- Postdoctoral Researcher at Stanford University School of Medicine, Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on neurological disorder treatments.
- PhD in Physics from Ohio University, specializing in the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks.

**Business & Financial Activity**
- No evidence of founding or co-founding any companies.

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**
- No litigation found directly involving Ali Khaledi Nasab. Cases with similar names exist but are unrelated.

**Academic / Public Recognition**
- Numerous publications in machine learning, AI, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics.
- Colloquium talk at the College of Wooster in 2017 on "Emergent Stochastic Oscillations and Signal Detection in Tree Networks of Excitable Elements."
- Received American Physical Society Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award in 2019.

**Online / Social Presence**
- Personal website: alikhaledi.com.
- Present on professional forums like Quantum Computing Stack Exchange and Software Engineering Stack Exchange (unconfirmed if it's the same individual).
- No verified social media presence found on Twitter, Facebook, or Instagram.
- Author page on Amazon Science.
- Google Scholar profile.


**Other Notable Mentions**
- Moved from Iran to the United States in 2014 for his PhD.

### Risk Profile

Based on the provided OSINT data, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a **low reputational risk**.  His background and activities suggest a dedicated academic and professional career focused on scientific research and development within reputable institutions.  No negative information was found regarding his financial activities or legal standing.

flagged_issues: Report states 'No verified social media presence found on Twitter, Facebook, or Instagram' but evidence only confirms absence of verified accounts, not absence of presence

Report mentions 'Present on professional forums like Quantum Computing Stack Exchange and Software Engineering Stack Exchange (unconfirmed if it's the same individual)' but evidence provides more detail about these profiles that could strengthen or weaken this connection
Missing citation for the claim about moving from Iran to US in 2014
Missing several specific publications mentioned in evidence that could strengthen academic profile
Report doesn't mention his 2024 appointment as Adjunct Professor of Physics at Ohio University
Report doesn't mention his role as editor for Brain Development section of Encyclopedia that won 2024 PROSE Award
judgement.revised_report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 11, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a scientist at Amazon Rufus, specializing in Generative AI products. He has a strong background in physics, neuroscience, and AI, including machine learning, deep learning, and computational neuroscience. There are no apparent red flags based on the provided OSINT data.

### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**
- Currently Scientist at Amazon Rufus, working on Generative AI products (as of 2024)¹
- Also serves as Applied Scientist at Amazon AGI Sensory Foundation Models¹⁰
- Previously Research Scientist at Amazon Web Services (AWS) in Network Capacity Planning¹
- Postdoctoral Researcher at Stanford University School of Medicine, Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on neurological disorder treatments including Parkinson's disease⁷
- PhD in Physics from Ohio University, specializing in the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks⁷
- Appointed as Adjunct Professor of Physics at Ohio University in 2024¹
- Affiliated with the Ronin Institute as a researcher¹

**Business & Financial Activity**
- No evidence of founding or co-founding any companies⁵

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**
- No litigation found directly involving Ali Khaledi Nasab. Cases with similar names exist but are unrelated¹¹

**Academic / Public Recognition**
- Numerous publications in machine learning, AI, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics²
- Notable publications include:
  - "Long-lasting desynchronization of plastic neural networks by random reset stimulation"²
  - "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge"²
  - "Impact of number of stimulation sites on long-lasting desynchronization effects of coordinated reset stimulation"²
- Colloquium talk at the College of Wooster in 2017 on "Emergent Stochastic Oscillations and Signal Detection in Tree Networks of Excitable Elements"⁶
- Received American Physical Society Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award in 2019⁶
- Editor for the Brain Development section of the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for significant contributions in Clinical Medicine¹

**Online / Social Presence**
- Personal website: alikhaledi.com¹
- Author page on Amazon Science¹⁰
- Google Scholar profile with verified publications²
- Possible presence on Quantum Computing Stack Exchange (user from Mashhad, Iran with matching research interests)¹²
- Possible presence on Software Engineering Stack Exchange (user from Mashhad, Iran with matching research interests)¹²
- No verified accounts found on Twitter, Facebook, or Instagram⁹
- Has authored articles on Medium (ali-khaledi1989.medium.com)⁵

**Other Notable Mentions**
- Originally from Iran, moved to the United States in 2014 for his PhD⁷
- Dedicates two hours daily to reading and coursework for continuous learning¹

### Risk Profile

Based on the provided OSINT data, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a **low reputational risk**. His background and activities suggest a dedicated academic and professional career focused on scientific research and development within reputable institutions. No negative information was found regarding his financial activities or legal standing.

---

2. Google Scholar profile (scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ)
3. [Not used]
4. [Not used]
5. ohio-forum.com, ali-khaledi1989.medium.com

7. alikhaledi.com/about

12. quantumcomputing.stackexchange.com, softwareengineering.stackexchange.com

([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai), [ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, he has authored articles on platforms like Medium, focusing on topics such as job interviews. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai)) His research interests encompass machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. task_6.query_used: Search news articles and press releases mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab in context of AI research or technology
task_6.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has made significant contributions to the field of physics, particularly in the study of excitable networks and sensory neurons. In October 2017, as a graduate student in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University, he delivered a colloquium at the College of Wooster titled "Emergent Stochastic Oscillations and Signal Detection in Tree Networks of Excitable Elements." His research focused on the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to sensory neurons like cat muscle spindles. The study demonstrated that the spontaneous activity of such networks could be predicted by analyzing a single effective node with scaled parameters, suggesting mechanisms for tuning the activity of central elements in these networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

In May 2019, Khaledi Nasab received a Student Travel Award from the American Physical Society's Division of Biological Physics, enabling him to present his paper, "Dynamics of Excitable Tree Networks: Application to Sensory Neurons," at the APS annual meeting in Boston. His research aimed to understand the dynamical principles of functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies, such as those found in muscle spindles, pain receptors, mechanoreceptors, and electroreceptors. Utilizing theoretical and computational approaches, he investigated mechanisms of spike generation and information coding in these neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

As of 2024, Khaledi Nasab is a Senior Researcher at Amazon in Seattle, United States, and also affiliated with the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

While his earlier work primarily focused on physics and neuroscience, there is no publicly available information directly linking Ali Khaledi Nasab to AI research or technology.

Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_7.query_used: Search university websites and faculty directories for Ali Khaledi Nasab's academic affiliations
task_7.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist with a diverse academic and professional background. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. in Physics at Ohio University, where he focused on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

After completing his doctorate, Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined the Department of Neurosurgery at Stanford University School of Medicine as a postdoctoral researcher. There, he worked on designing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

In 2022, he transitioned to the tech industry, joining Amazon Web Services (AWS) as a research scientist in the Network Capacity Planning organization. By 2024, he moved to Amazon Rufus to work on their latest Generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his roles at Amazon, Dr. Khaledi Nasab serves as an adjunct professor of Physics at Ohio University, a position he began in 2024. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has contributed to various fields, including physics, neuroscience, and artificial intelligence, reflecting his interdisciplinary expertise and commitment to advancing scientific knowledge.

task_11.query_used: Search court records and legal databases for any litigation involving Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_11.data:
After searching court records and legal databases, I found no litigation involving an individual named "Ali Khaledi Nasab." It's possible that such records are not publicly available, the individual has not been involved in any legal proceedings, or the name may be spelled differently in legal documents.

However, I did find cases involving individuals with similar names:

1. **Khaledi v. Global Trading Ltd HAR (2003):** This case involved Heydar "Shaun" Khaledi in a business dispute with H.K. Global Trading, Ltd. and others. The litigation centered around a temporary injunction related to a business disagreement among the Khaledi brothers. ([caselaw.findlaw.com](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/court/tx-court-of-appeals/1109873.html?utm_source=openai))

2. **Kholghi v. Aliabadi (2020):** This Tennessee Court of Appeals case involved Sima Khayatt Kholghi and Reza Aliabadi in a divorce proceeding. The court addressed issues related to the division of marital assets and debts. ([law.justia.com](https://law.justia.com/cases/tennessee/court-of-appeals/2020/m2019-01793-coa-r3-cv.html?utm_source=openai))

3. **Alami v. Khalid (2024):** In this Ohio Court of Appeals case, Ali Alami filed a complaint against Hassan Khalid and others concerning a joint venture to purchase equipment. The dispute involved claims of replevin, money damages, and unjust enrichment. ([casetext.com](https://casetext.com/case/alami-v-khalid?utm_source=openai))

Please note that these cases involve individuals with similar but not identical names to "Ali Khaledi Nasab." If you have additional information, such as alternative spellings, locations, or specific case details, I can assist further in locating relevant records.
